<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module7_mcq_q73')" data-correct-answer="C">
<strong style="display: block;">In a world without taxes, which statement best describes the relationship between a firm's financial leverage and its equity beta?</strong>

<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q73" value="A"> A. The equity beta decreases with leverage because debt absorbs risk.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q73" value="B"> B. Leverage has no effect on beta in perfect capital markets.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q73" value="C"> C. Leverage amplifies the equity beta because equity holders face greater volatility of returns.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q73" value="D"> D. The equity beta only changes if the cost of debt increases.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q73" value="E"> E. The asset beta becomes more volatile with leverage, not the equity beta.</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module7_mcq_q73" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
âœ… Correct: C. Financial leverage magnifies the sensitivity of equity returns to market risk.  
In a no-tax world, the relationship is given by $\beta_E = \beta_U(1 + \frac{D}{E})$, showing that as $D/E$ rises, $\beta_E$ increases proportionally.
